title: Between 21 July 2017 and 20 July 2018, will any major automaker announce a date after which they will sell only electric or hybrid vehicles?
preds: Volvo announces to only produce electro vehicles from 2019

Even funnier, it seems that there is already one of the companies listed in the infographic (London Taxi Company, renamed in September 2017 to London EV Company) that only sells electric vehicles (exactly one of them) - not at any date in the future but now, since January 2018. 
https://electriccarsreport.com/2017/07/london-taxi-company-becomes-levc/
https://www.levc.com/
Don't think there ever was an announcement of the ridiculous kind that this question seems to imply ("lest you doubt it, we, the EV company, will not be selling ICE vehicles")
The consensus is 5% but guys I follow are at 0%
Just going to zero due to the time frame.

None of the major brands would put all its eggs in one basket on a technology where the infrastructure is completely not ready. For the manufacturers to produce only electric cars, there must be equal if not more service/charging stations to that of the current petrol/gasoline stations.
Just 11 days left and my last forecast of 5% was on 22 March.
As of now the interest in combustion engine vehicles is still to high but since china is going to ban fossile fueled cars some automakers may change their mind
Yes it was anounced but will the hybrid version.
Volvo did announced it in beginning of July - but so far no other will follow this example.

Although per barrel oil prices have risen by double-digit increases over the last 2 years, the increase was very gradual, and therefore has not presented much of a shock for consumers to notice. With the world economy still growing, and consumer optimism remaining high, many will not see the financial incentive to switch away from fossil fuels, in order to justify the  purchase of  a more expensive EV or Hybrid vehicle.  This market will eventually grow, but will take more time, along with possibly significant disruption within the global oil supply system.
The seeming inevitability of electric/hybrid technology surpassing ice tech.
FWIW, I have finally received a reply from GJO:
Some announcements lately of car makers adding electric and hybrid lines, but it doesn't look like anybody is ready yet to make the leap all the way.
Back to zero. Apparently, the DS announcement did not make the cut.

Technically, it seems to me that the DS announcement doesn't quite cut it. They talk about ''new models'' being exclusively electric and hybrid after 2025, not that all cars they sell (or make) will meet this condition. So the announcement is consistent with DS offering a mix of vehicles after 2025 - both electric/hybrid and other kind. Note that the critical distinction is, in my view, not between "sell'' and "make"', but between "models' and "vehicles". Raising my forecast a bit nonetheless, on the chance I am wrong.
Have read a number of other reports on this. Vague wording but does sound like DS will be all electric or hybrid by 2025. No older petrol only models by 2025.

Thanks @N-P ...
I should have been more conscious of the wording of the question. The DS announcement Does give date of 2025. Wow - they make Tesla look like a volume manufacturer (50 000 units).

@Anneinak, @Emil, @cdob63, @Hammer-Time

Decreasing as Q1 earnings season is over (or nearly over), eliminating potential catalysts for an announcement.

A Chinese company will be making only electric vehicles, but unfortunately, they're not considered a "major automaker" according to the chart.  The Ora iQ5 has debuted for Great Wall's brand which will sell only electric vehicles, prototypes of a 4.5m long crossover have been seen with 'ORA' in large letters on the tailgate, brand is 'Oula' in Chinese.

Lowering with the passage of time.

Read Paper by Louis Lambilliotte, June 2015,  and convenience: the True Challenge of Electric Vehicle Adoption by Samantha Tung.  while these challenges are being addressed certainly not by July 20, 2018
decreasing from 15% to 14% due to passage of time
Sticking to zero. Re. The Porsche comments, context is required - don’t believe combustion engines would be completely abandoned.
Excerpt from the first article link below (a 3/16/18 interview with Porsche Executive Board Chairman Blume):

Starting point: My sense of history is that it is rare for a large business to announce the complete scrapping of a profitable business segment. So my starting point is an assumption of a low base rate (0-20%)
Because of the passage of time.

While electric & hybrid vehicles are the way of the future, I don't believe the evolution / adoption of this technology has been growing as it was originally forecast.  More importantly, I don't believe that there is any real upside for an automaker to come out with such a significant public announcement.
popularity of electric and electric hybrids is increasing steadily yet traditional fossil fuel vehicles are predicted to be the major portion of sales worldwide.

Lowering my estimate given July 20 is close and my original estimate was too high.  A hard date for going fully electric and/or hybrid is unlikely to be announced by major US brands.  These announcements are likely to come several years from now.  Additionally, major European brands' shareholders would probably throw a fit.
Yes, it already happened with Volvo.
In the current news climate there is little benefit in terms of PR for a company to make such an announcement just now.
Passage of time update, plus the current trend described below:
No thinking head of marketing will "Osborne" the current vehicles he is selling by committing to a future elimination of those vehicles for some very limited PR.

VAG group seems to be planning to produce electric cars as "sub-brands" under its current main brands. They don't seem to be tempted to announce a date to stop selling non-electric and non-hybrid cars. I am not sure why any major auto group would want to do so.
We aren't there yet.  Subaru is not listed on your infographic.
Several sources have announced that Land Rover has commited to an entirely hybrid or electric power train.
They're too big to eliminate all gas/diesel engines

FWIW: Auto manufacturers sometimes time significant announcements to coincide with auto shows. After Geneva (happening now), not many large auto shows left before a summer break -- and the end of this question. Notable ones (arguably) remaining on the docket before summer are Bangkok (3/27/18), New York (3/30/18), and Beijing (4/25/18).
Revising downward due to the passage of time.
Volvo has said they will stop designing ICE-based cars in 2019.

I'm answering this with caveats.  Very few automakers in the linked infographic have the guts to announce hard dates - let alone something as bold as no longer producing gasoline powered vehicles.  Volvo is in prime position to be the first automaker to make this announcement considering their announcement to produce the electric and hybrid chassis for their vehicles and with their withdraw from the ETC racing circuit; but they won't give up on the gasoline engines until well in to the 2020's.
Hmm. Odd question since Volvo has already announced this. anyway, there is a Renault car brand named Samsung??? What???
Conditions are getting tighter and tighter for diesel and gas vehicles in major cities.

Volvo will continue through 2021-25 to make and sell models that were conceived and introduced up to mid-2018. Their most successful models are high-hp IC-driven vehicles like the XC90, XC60, and S90, will continue to be manufactured. Only all their NEW models will be all EVs, after mid-2019. so, Not quite yet...
Some European auto companies have already said so
Yes, but the date will be as much as 4 years ahead.

No automaker will announce writing off their massive investment in Internal Combustion Engines, nor will they take the risk, nor they can do it in the short term. What will it happen is a number of announcements of EV brands, but not full substitution.

dsarin's post of the KPMG report.

No doubt - it should be common knowledge that this is the future and if history is any indication, as soon as one automaker announces a major change, the rest that can will follow.  Anyone not innovating will go out of business.  Not only do I predict that another automaker will announce this, but I predict more than one will.
I can imagine one of the PSA, GM or Volkswagen brands making such an announcement, but I doubt that it will happen so soon.
Lowering due to passing of time.  By 2020, it is likely that one or more car makers will make the announcement, but this is simply too soon to expect it.
There still need for combustion engine on our planet

There is a huge wide range of vehicle manufacturers represented in the infographic even one subdivision of those Vehicles could very possibly announced that it will only sell electric vehicles under those makes.
They are going to announce with the wave of sales of hybrid and electric cars.

Per tetbury, maybe as PR exercise but not grounded in reality. Electricity varies from highly renewable (hydro-electric even if damaging to river systems to outright nasty coal and tar sands based heavy oil). Toss in inefficient storage and range anxiety and most people are status quo. With better battery tech, better alternative power sources the time will come. Has it been raised by anyone that autonomous autos require such gnificantly more energy to run (maybe they’re mining crypto currency while driving in addition to processor, lidar, and occupants streaming Netflix...  long winded way of saying 0%
Passage of time and very strict criteria of the question as discussed before.

Passage of time. Such an announcement would only be a PR exercise by announcing some date so far in the future as to be meaningless, especially as most of the media is happy to report press releases that only say that a manufacturer has said "after yyyy we will not introduce any new non-electric or hybrid cars" as if the manufacturer has said "after yyyy we will not make or sell anything but electric and hybrid cars".

Coal powered cars (aka ‘electric’) are not practical on large scale due to infrastructure.  To power them in quantity would require major investment in nuclear and/or coal plants and electrical distribution.  It’s practical for small niche market, but not for major manufacturers.
Volvo has taken the initiative,  but manufacturers like Volkswagen, Toyota, and GM have had extensive involvement with electrification.

GM announced in October of 2017.  With their commitment to an all-electric/hybrid product line in the near (date as yet undetermined) future, profitability dictates (their words) that they focus on one manufacturing type rather than keeping both lines going.  To be more specific, they currently lose money on each electric unit sold of the Bolt.  In order to shift that to a positive there needs to be improvements in scalability and cost of the technologies needed for these types of vehicles.
they will be lease cars designed for the young who cannot afford new cars
Volvo already did, so not sure i quite understand....
volvo seems to be headed toward EV only manufacturing
Very slim chance that any major auto maker will make that announcement that soon without seeing Volvo's results.
Smart and Volvo have already. There is nobody left in the industry at this moment.
The wording of the question is too specific to be satisfied by any announcement - which is often vague.
To produce only electric cars could be devastating to the respective manufacturer in the American market which is a significant market for all "major" manufacturers.

Electric cars will fail, but we'll build them anyway, say global auto execs
62 percent of decision-makers at automakers and their suppliers have a dim view of electric cars.
76 percent of automotive executives believe internal-combustion engines will continue as the dominant global drivetrain for many years to come.
78 percent of respondents think the breakthrough technology of the future for road vehicles will be hydrogen fuel cells.
https://assets.kpmg.com/content/dam/kpmg/xx/pdf/2017/01/global-automotive-executive-survey-2017.pdf

It is very unlikely for any single carmaker making this kind of anouncement, since it seems to not only involves ceasing to produce non-electric vehicles, but also a stop on selling older models on other markets (This assumption depends on the degree cars are produced on-demand, if someone could point me to some information regarding that, it would be nice). However, the probability of one of many (14) doing something each single one is unlikely to do is usually still not too small:
If we assume independency and each single manufacturer has a chance of 1.5% to make the announcment in the given time, the chance of one of them doing it becomes almost 20%. I correct this downwards by 5% in order to account for the lack of total independency.
Infinity already announced they would start phasing out gasoline models in 2021 around the 1st of this year.
Politics plays into this as well. Gas prices are low, and the current government will keep them there, so there's no incentive to be the first to go all electric or hybrid.
Recent announcements from manufacturers talking about 2021 as their target date, means that there is no courage from these companies to do anything on this this year. Sad. But, reality.
What would be rationale for doing this?  It's too early in the electric car development to predict the shift, which might not ever come.

My judgement is, that within the given timeframe (until July 2018) the chance is very very low that any major automaker will announce such a radical change from its current course. What meansin effect; we should already know by now of such possible announcement.

Agree with others that have stated that this probability is very low. Don't see what can be gained by making such an announcement by mid-2018 - if the announced date is relatively soon, the automaker would be voluntarily reducing their market share (suicidal for any CEO), and if it is in the distant future, it's kind of pointless. Zero may look too categorical (anything can happen), but in practice the difference in terms of accuracy between a probability of zero vs low single digit is negligible.
Major auto execs are saying slower than expected adoption of electric assuming this includes hybrids so petrol is only sure option for next six months
A major automaker will be unable to project a date and make this announcement with certainty so soon, because the actual date of such an occurrence likely will be a decade or more in the future.

Electric vehicles only make sense, when you can create and STORE electricity without CO2. Until you have battery capacity on the grid at great scale - and that is not the case yet and in the foreseeable future - electric vehicles are just expensive toys for the rich but not for the average Joe. Major automakers would be stupid to announce something like that. For the record: I don't take Tesla as a major automaker.

I think many brands that could make this statement, but most will not.  But the question is will any...  I see this as a bit of a similar situation to CVS saying they would stop selling cigarettes.  The calculus is that even though a large amount revenue comes from the discontinued items, the overall image and opportunity to differentiate makes it worth doing.

Making such an announcement just to make positive green press is possible, but it is unlikely to happen within the time constraints given due to cheap oil, long development cycles, and current economy of scale.

Certainly not. Although Volvo will be equipping all cars with electric engines from 2019 onwards, I think it will be completely utopian for the foreseeable future to do without combustion engines for large manufacturers. In the industrialized countries, the entire infrastructure and buyers' attitudes continue to be geared towards internal combustion engines. The premiums that the German government has made available for e-vehicles are turning into shelf warmers. Even in times of the VW diesel scandal, electric cars are absolute niche products in Europe's most important automobile market.

i tend to become more pessimistic over this question since there are a couple of near miss to meet the questions request.  I assume that if at all only a luxury carmaker will announce such a radical change. Saab would be a candidate but no more existing too sad.
No, because it Is the wrong way at the moment
There is no incentive yet to make that corporate-level leap.

The cost differential between exploration, extraction, distilling and the distribution of fossil fuels can only increase parabolically over time.  In contrast hybrid and electric fuel systems can only become more efficient and economically viable due to technology refinements of battery cell storage that will improve efficiencies over time.
Gas/diesel vehicles will continue to have a nitch for the major auto manufacturers.

Coming down in light of the clarification. It's unlikely that any automaker will announce the total discontinuation of gasoline-powered cars. Many have announced some degree of "electrification" of their lines: Volvo, Jaguar Land Rover, Opel, GM, Lincoln, Honda, Toyota. Most of these companies have announced that they will offer an electric option for every model after a certain date.
Dropping a few points because everything I read seems to partial electric and hybrid fleets or expanding sales of the two types of vehicles.
In fact Toyota has made such an announcement. They expect to be making only electric and hybrid vehicles by the mid 2020s.

Any company that went all electric would effectively be excluding themselves from the US market. You can't make money on electric vehicles in the United States because not enough people want them. Car companies sell their electric and hybrid vehicles at a loss and then make their money by selling SUVs at inflated prices. The US government forces auto companies to keep their miles per gallon Fleet average at a certain place, and so this forces them to sell their more fuel-efficient vehicles at a loss in order to get their Fleet average down and then they make up their money on the SUVs and trucks. Why would they cut off their income source and focus only on the products that are losing them money?

as @jayb has said yesterday Mazda does appear to have provided a date (or at least a year) by which they will only be offering  electric and hybrid vehicles, but they are missing from the infographic list, so do not count for this question.
http://www.autoexpress.co.uk/mazda/100819/mazda-to-electrify-entire-range-by-2035
 I suppose a date of 2035 fits with the dates by which countries such as France and UK have said they will ban the sale of traditional ICE cars. From a practical point of view giving a date 18 years in the future is painless, who will remember what Mazda said in 2017 in 18 years time. Will Mazda exist by then? Personally I doubt that new hybrid cars will be around in 2035 as they only provide a small improvement over ICE only cars.
But if Mazda thinks it worth making announcements about what it plans to produce in 15 or 20 years time then I have to admit that other makers might feel its pretty safe to do the same, after all any executive over 50 years old will have retired before we find out if the announcement was just hot air. 
I had previously been assuming that an "announcement" would mean that there was actually a commitment to a plan to do something within the next model cycle (5 to 7 years)  as per the Volvo announcement, but the question does not seem to rule out announcing what will take place in 15, 20 or 200 years time. The question does not require us to believe them.

Somehow, Mazda (independent car manufacturer) doesn't appear to be listed on this question's infographic...

The probability should be very high considering the convergence of disruptions taking place in energy sector (cost of production of solar based energy, battery technology, cost of storage of energy, charging technology and power systems) where in the electric vehicles cost parity is practical for users to make decision over ICE based vehicles by 2020. However the penetration of electric vehicles of total fleet is minimal and the amount of capital invested in traditional auto industry (technology, aftermarket, supply chain) is not easy to leave behind so easily (it will also impact the competences - both new and the ones that would be obsolete) so even if companies are ready, society and markets would not be ready.
Although we can expect a few more companies taking similar positions to volvo, I am not that not optimistic for the next couple of months.

I read yesterday that Mazda has had a breakthrough in gasoline engine technology that will improve efficiency by about 30%.   This will delay the transition to all electric vehicles.  (https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/cars/2017/08/08/mazda-gasoline-engine-brekathrough/549234001/)

While a corporation is unlikely to surrender its profit potential by only manufacturing electric or hybrid vehicles, pressure from policy makers and the global shift to renewables following the Paris agreement may convince auto manufacturers to comply.  Countries such as India have already announced future dates in which electric or hybrid car will be the only ones produced.  This, however, generally targets the demographic of urban dwellers.  While more and more people are migrating to cities, a significant portion of their profit potential is in jeopardy by abandoning the gas model.  This, though, is predicated on the cost of gas over the long run.  Many factors still have to be revealed.
Do not understand the likelihood of major automaker wilfully surrendering profits like this in what remains a new uncertain climate for car sales.

Despite the popularity of Tesla showing the level of interest in electric cars in the community, such pronouncement from major automakers would serve little value beyond grabbing headlines. By ramping up production of electric and hybrid vehicles, and not making such announcements, they maintain the option to adjust their manufacturing blend as they see fit. Unless mandated by governments, such announcements would unnecessarily (and possibly prematurely) corner the manufacturer into a commitment.

It seems that nations are setting the more ambitious goals of eliminating internal combustion vehicles more so than companies (https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2017/08/03/three-european-countries-say-theyre-done-with-fossil-fueled-cars-can-the-rest-of-the-world-catch-up/?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_toyota-mazda-1050a%3Ahomepage%2Fstory), although as @Tetbury points out, no one is talking about ending sales of used vehicles but instead only of new sales.

I seem to be well away from the consensus on this question. There is a lot of difference between announcing, as Volvo has, a date after which new models will be electric or hybrid and announcing a date after which you will only sell electric or hybrid cars. Volvo has given itself the option of continuing to sell non-electric or hybrid cars for 5 or 10  or 20 years after 2019. All it has to say is that the petrol or diesel only cars are continuations of existing models. How long did VW produce the Beetle or the Gulf? There is no hard definition of a "new" model. 
It would be very risky for a car manufacturer to announce it was stopping selling pure ICE cars, because there could be technical or commercial problems if it did so. For example there will almost certainty be parts of the world that have no charging points for electric cars by 2020, and although Volvo is a premium brand there will be countries and people who will not want to pay for a hybrid.  It would be far safer to continue with the ICE cars until demand drops.  Certainly there will be countries and people who will want to only pay for a basic ICE non-premium branded car until well after 2020.
Accepting my overconfidence bias may have pushed me too far. Need to look deeper into the question.
In the next year? Yeah I think this one is very, very probable.

As noted below, 7/27/17 reported (partial) quotation from Fiat Chrysler CEO Sergio Marchionne (ref. first source linked below):  
"I think we’re now in a position to acknowledge that at least one of our brands, and in particular Maserati, will, when it completes the development of its next two models, effectively switch all of its portfolio to electrification and as these products come up for renewal post 2019 it will start launching vehicles which are all electric and which will ... be considered state-of-the-art technology..."
Other brands will watch reaction to Volvo's announcement and if positive may set a date more than 10 years out.

There are a few of issues with this question.
1. Volvo has not announced a date after which it will only sell all-electric or hybrid-electric vehicles. What was announced was that all new models after 2019 would be electric or hybrid, presumably it will continue to sell  as new models introduced before 2019 for a significant number of years after 2019.  
2. The question refers to "vehicles", Many of the "brands" in the infographic (including the Volvo brand) are used on vehicles other than cars (e.g. Trucks, Construction vehicles, agricultural vehicles etc. It is likely that non-electric versions of these will continue for longer. The question refers to vehicles the infographic refers to cars. 
3. The recent announcements that France and the UK would phase out petrol and diesel powered cars includes hybrids, but excludes other types of internal combustion engines (e.g. hydrogen, LPG. So assuming that in some markets hybrids are seen as part of the problem but in other markets hybrids are seen as being part of the solution it could be that the US would want hybrids and Europe would ban them. Petrol could be out but hydrogen could be in. 
It is possible that a small brand belonging to a big company could go all electric e.g. the DS brand of the PSA Group.
Announcing a date for a goal is simple, good PR, and can always be modified.

So in my personal opinion, there's only 38 possible companies.

First, it seems very unlikely for a brand of a company to make such announcement. Brand-level announcement would be defeating the purpose of publicity and make little sense - with some exceptions, but exceptions are mostly for companies that could make announcement as a whole (VW, for example). So then which of the 14 companies could make such announcement: FCA - almost 100% no. Daimler - maybe but <30% chance. Ford - maybe but probably less than 35% chance. Toyota, Honda, Nissan, Hyundai - I think Japanese don't like such flashy PR; same for Koreans, so likely no. Geely - possible, although they did it with Volvo already and it's not clear whether Chinese brand would make sense. Tata - not likely. PSA - likely, probably over 50% chance. Renault - likely, probably over 50% chance. BMW - maybe, below 35%. GM - not likely. VW - very likely, probably over 60%.

With so many brands of cars represented in this inforgraphic, surely one more besides Volvo would step out and announce a future date. A future date. Why not. Within the decade we will see more sustainable vehicles on the road than ever before - regardless of tax incentives and rebates. It is bound to happen.
I'm surprised this hasn't already happened. It will surely happen in a year.
This would be a marketing ploy rather than a real commitment to fighting climate change.

Given that Ferrari has also made this move (in addition to the mentioned Polestar/Volvo), it'd be hard not to see at least a dying brand make the announcement. I could see a brand like Lancia make a last ditch effort to save themselves. Another consideration is that Nissan and Renault together have huge investment with electric vehicles, having one of their brands announced to be hybrid or electric wouldn't be a shock. You also have the highest performing cars using hybrid systems (F1, LMP, Porsche 918 and Panamera, McLaren P1, Acura NSX) allowing for a trickle down of their technologies to a whole brand.
A date announcement is also a promotional event

This doesn't seem likely at all based on the requirement for the major automaker to only sell electric or hybrid vehicles globally. If it was constrained to just the European and/or US markets, I think it would be a possibility. But to expect the major automakers to also either only sell these in other markets or to pull out of those markets (Asia, Africa, Middle East, Latin America) doesn't provide incentive to these automakers.
